questions.question_text: What is an operating system in the context of computing?

options.A: A network protocol that routes data packets between computers connected to the internet
options.B: A physical circuit board that coordinates electrical signals between the CPU and memory chips
options.C: System software that manages computer hardware and software resources and provides common services for programs
options.D: A programming language used to write applications and compile them into machine code

questions.question_text: What is the Internet?

options.A: A local wireless connection standard that links personal devices within a single home or office building
options.B: A satellite broadcasting system that transmits television and radio signals to receivers located around the world
options.C: A single centralized server maintained by an international organization that hosts all publicly accessible websites worldwide
options.D: The global system of interconnected computer networks that uses the TCP/IP protocol suite to communicate between networks and devices

questions.question_text: In computing, what is a database?

options.A: A backup power supply unit that preserves electronically stored data during unexpected electrical outages
options.B: An organized collection of data stored electronically and managed through a database management system (DBMS)
options.C: A type of spreadsheet application designed exclusively for calculating and displaying financial records
options.D: A physical filing cabinet system used to archive printed documents and paper records in offices

questions.question_text: What best describes a computer network?

options.A: A software program that connects a computer's internal components such as the CPU and memory
options.B: A group of interconnected computers that communicate and share resources using communication protocols
options.C: A single computer with multiple monitors attached for displaying different applications on each screen
options.D: A collection of websites organized into categories and indexed for retrieval by a search engine

questions.question_text: What does the term 'software' refer to in computing?

options.A: The metal and plastic casing that protects the internal circuitry of a computer from damage
options.B: Computer programs and associated data that provide instructions telling a computer what to do
options.C: The physical electronic components inside a computer such as the processor and memory chips
options.D: The electrical wiring and cable connections that link peripheral devices to the motherboard

questions.question_text: What distinguishes a computer virus from other types of malicious software?

options.A: It spreads independently across networks without needing to attach itself to any existing programs
options.B: It replicates by modifying other computer programs and inserting its own code into those programs
options.C: It monitors keyboard input to secretly record passwords and send them to a remote attacker
options.D: It encrypts all files on a hard drive and demands a cryptocurrency ransom payment to restore access

questions.question_text: What is cloud computing?

options.A: A method of storing files exclusively on portable USB flash drives for secure offline access anywhere
options.B: A weather prediction system that uses networked satellites to model atmospheric conditions and forecast storms
options.C: The on-demand delivery of computing resources such as servers, storage, and applications over the internet
options.D: A local area network setup where all desktop computers share a single centralized physical hard drive

questions.question_text: What does the term 'computer hardware' refer to?

options.A: The set of rules and protocols that govern how data is transmitted between devices on a network
options.B: The physical components of a computer, such as the CPU, RAM, motherboard, and storage devices
options.C: The graphical user interface elements like windows, icons, and menus displayed on a monitor screen
options.D: The programs and applications installed on a computer that enable users to perform specific tasks

questions.question_text: In computing, what is a file system?

options.A: A method used by an operating system to organize, store, and retrieve files on a storage device
options.B: A cloud-based service that automatically backs up all user files to a remote internet server
options.C: An antivirus program that scans documents for malicious code before allowing them to be opened
options.D: A hardware component inside a hard drive that physically reads and writes data to the disk platters

questions.question_text: In computer security, what is a password?

options.A: A biometric fingerprint scan stored on an encrypted chip embedded inside the computer's motherboard
options.B: An encrypted file containing the user's complete browsing history and all saved website preferences
options.C: A secret string of characters used to authenticate a user's identity and grant access to a system
options.D: A hardware security token that generates a unique radio frequency signal to physically unlock a device

questions.question_text: The Open Source Definition maintained by the Open Source Initiative was originally based on which set of guidelines?

options.A: The MIT License framework developed at Massachusetts Institute of Technology
options.B: The GNU General Public License terms drafted by Richard Stallman
options.C: The Debian Free Software Guidelines, written primarily by Bruce Perens
options.D: The Apache Software Foundation's licensing principles

questions.question_text: What was the name of the first web browser, and who created it in 1990?

options.A: Navigator, created by James Gosling at Sun Microsystems
options.B: Nexus, created by Robert Cailliau at MIT
options.C: Mosaic, created by Marc Andreessen at the University of Illinois
options.D: WorldWideWeb, created by Tim Berners-Lee at CERN

questions.question_text: In 1947, a team working on the Harvard Mark II computer taped an insect into their logbook, an incident that helped popularize the computing term 'bug.' What type of insect was it?

options.A: A fly caught in the paper tape reader mechanism
options.B: A beetle found lodged inside a vacuum tube
options.C: An ant discovered shorting a circuit on the main board
options.D: A moth found stuck between relay contacts

questions.question_text: Who proposed the relational model for databases in 1970 while working at IBM, publishing the influential paper 'A Relational Model of Data for Large Shared Data Banks'?

options.A: Michael Stonebraker, developer of Ingres and PostgreSQL
options.B: Charles Bachman, creator of the network data model
options.C: Edgar F. Codd (E. F. Codd)
options.D: Donald Chamberlin, co-inventor of SQL

questions.question_text: SQL was originally developed at IBM under a different name that had to be changed due to a trademark conflict. What was that original name?

options.A: SEQUEL (Structured English Query Language)
options.B: SQUARE (Specifying Queries Using A Relational Engine)
options.C: ISAM (Indexed Sequential Access Method)
options.D: QUEL (Query Language for relational databases)

questions.question_text: The TCP/IP model organizes Internet communication protocols into four abstraction layers. From lowest to highest, what are these layers?

options.A: Physical layer, Data link layer, Network layer, Session layer
options.B: Access layer, Network layer, Host layer, Process layer
options.C: Hardware layer, Routing layer, Connection layer, Service layer
options.D: Link layer, Internet layer, Transport layer, Application layer

questions.question_text: Linus Torvalds created Git in 2005 for Linux kernel development after losing access to which proprietary version control system?

options.A: ClearCase, whose IBM licensing fees became too expensive for the project
options.B: BitKeeper, whose free license was revoked for Linux developers
options.C: Perforce, which ended its open-source partnership with the kernel team
options.D: Subversion (SVN), which could not handle the kernel's repository size

questions.question_text: Which programming language, developed in Norway during 1961-1967, is generally accepted as the first language to introduce classes, inheritance, and dynamic binding?

options.A: LISP, developed by John McCarthy at MIT
options.B: Simula, developed by Ole-Johan Dahl and Kristen Nygaard
options.C: C++, developed by Bjarne Stroustrup at Bell Labs
options.D: Smalltalk, developed by Alan Kay and Dan Ingalls at Xerox PARC

questions.question_text: In operating systems, what is the key distinction between a program and a process?

options.A: A program is compiled code while a process is interpreted code running in a virtual machine
options.B: A program can use multiple CPUs while a process is limited to a single core
options.C: A program runs in kernel mode while a process runs in user mode only
options.D: A program is a passive set of instructions on disk; a process is an active instance being executed in memory

questions.question_text: In virtual memory systems, what hardware component in the CPU automatically translates virtual addresses to physical addresses?

options.A: The memory management unit (MMU)
options.B: The arithmetic logic unit (ALU)
options.C: The translation lookaside buffer (TLB) controller
options.D: The direct memory access (DMA) controller

questions.question_text: In a modern CPU's cache hierarchy, which level of cache is the smallest, fastest, and located closest to each processor core?

options.A: L1 cache, which is typically 16-128 KB per core and can be accessed in as little as one clock cycle
options.B: The register file, which functions as a 1 MB cache layer between the ALU and main memory
options.C: L2 cache, which is shared between pairs of cores and accessed in two clock cycles
options.D: L3 cache, which is embedded directly in the core and uses SRAM for single-cycle access

questions.question_text: The Diffie-Hellman key exchange, published in 1976, was the first publicly disclosed protocol enabling what cryptographic capability?

options.A: Establishing a shared secret between two parties over an insecure channel without prior shared secrets
options.B: Digitally signing documents to verify the sender's identity using hash functions
options.C: Generating one-time pads for provably unbreakable encryption of military communications
options.D: Encrypting messages using a single symmetric key distributed by a trusted authority

questions.question_text: In software testing, what distinguishes white-box testing from black-box testing?

options.A: White-box testing runs only on production systems, while black-box testing runs only in development environments
options.B: White-box testing examines the internal structure and source code, while black-box testing only validates functionality against specifications
options.C: White-box testing focuses on performance benchmarks, while black-box testing focuses on security vulnerabilities
options.D: White-box testing is performed by end users, while black-box testing is performed by developers

questions.question_text: REST, one of the most widely used API architectural styles, was defined by Roy Fielding in his 2000 doctoral dissertation. What does the statelessness constraint of REST require?

options.A: All API responses must be in stateless formats like plain text, prohibiting structured data like JSON or XML
options.B: Clients must re-authenticate with a full handshake for every single API request they make
options.C: Each client request must contain all information needed to process it, with no stored context on the server between requests
options.D: The server must maintain a session object for each client to track authentication tokens across calls

questions.question_text: Functional programming has its theoretical roots in a formal system developed in the 1930s. What is this foundational mathematical framework?

options.A: Turing machines, developed by Alan Turing to model sequential imperative computation with state
options.B: Boolean algebra, developed by George Boole to formalize logical reasoning in binary terms
options.C: The lambda calculus, developed by Alonzo Church as a formal system for expressing computation through function abstraction
options.D: Set theory, developed by Georg Cantor as a framework for defining collections and membership operations

questions.question_text: A stateful inspection firewall improves upon simple packet filtering by maintaining what additional information when deciding whether to allow network traffic?

options.A: A DNS cache mapping all domain names to IP addresses for faster routing decisions
options.B: A state table tracking active connections, so it can determine whether packets belong to an established session
options.C: A log of all user login credentials to verify application-level authentication per packet
options.D: A complete copy of every packet's payload for deep content inspection and virus scanning

questions.question_text: In concurrent programming, four conditions must hold simultaneously for a deadlock to occur. Which of the following is one of these four necessary conditions?

options.A: Livelock: two threads continually change state in response to each other without making any progress
options.B: Starvation: a thread is perpetually denied access to a resource because other threads always take precedence
options.C: Priority inversion: a high-priority thread is blocked indefinitely while a low-priority thread runs continuously
options.D: Circular wait: a circular chain of threads exists where each thread holds a resource the next thread is waiting for

questions.question_text: The CAP theorem, conjectured by Eric Brewer in 2000, states that a distributed data store cannot simultaneously guarantee which three properties?

options.A: Concurrency, atomicity, and performance
options.B: Consistency, availability, and partition tolerance
options.C: Correctness, accessibility, and portability
options.D: Confidentiality, authentication, and persistence

questions.question_text: Third Normal Form (3NF), defined by Edgar F. Codd, requires that a relation in 2NF must additionally eliminate what type of dependency?

options.A: Partial dependencies, where a non-key attribute depends on only part of a composite primary key
options.B: Multivalued dependencies, where one attribute determines a set of values for another independent attribute
options.C: Join dependencies, where a table cannot be reconstructed from a decomposition into smaller tables
options.D: Transitive dependencies, where a non-prime attribute depends on another non-prime attribute rather than directly on the primary key

questions.question_text: In compiler design, the first phase of compilation reads source code character by character and groups characters into meaningful sequences called tokens. What is this phase called?

options.A: Lexical analysis (also known as scanning or tokenization)
options.B: Syntax analysis, which builds an abstract syntax tree from the token stream
options.C: Semantic analysis, which checks type compatibility and scoping rules
options.D: Preprocessing, which expands macros and resolves include directives before compilation

questions.question_text: In compiler design, what is the first phase of compilation that reads source code characters and groups them into meaningful units called tokens?

options.A: Syntax analysis
options.B: Intermediate code generation
options.C: Lexical analysis
options.D: Semantic analysis

questions.question_text: Which category of instruction set architecture does the x86 processor family (used by Intel and AMD) belong to?

options.A: Complex Instruction Set Computing (CISC)
options.B: Explicitly Parallel Instruction Computing (EPIC)
options.C: Very Long Instruction Word (VLIW)
options.D: Reduced Instruction Set Computing (RISC)

questions.question_text: Which two Linux kernel features does Docker use to provide process isolation and resource control for containers, rather than using a hypervisor?

options.A: Namespaces and cgroups (control groups)
options.B: SELinux and AppArmor
options.C: Hypervisor and virtual machine monitor
options.D: Swap partitions and memory-mapped files

questions.question_text: In the Domain Name System, which type of DNS record maps a human-readable domain name to an IPv4 address?

options.A: CNAME record
options.B: A record
options.C: NS record
options.D: MX record

questions.question_text: Which computer scientist invented garbage collection around 1959 to simplify memory management in the Lisp programming language?

options.A: Edsger Dijkstra
options.B: John McCarthy
options.C: Donald Knuth
options.D: Alan Turing

questions.question_text: Compared to TLS 1.2 which requires two round trips, how many round trips does a TLS 1.3 handshake require to establish a new secure connection?

options.A: Two round trips (2-RTT)
options.B: One round trip (1-RTT)
options.C: Zero round trips (0-RTT)
options.D: Three round trips (3-RTT)

questions.question_text: Which two Google engineers introduced the MapReduce programming model in their 2004 paper for processing large datasets on clusters?

options.A: Sergey Brin and Larry Page
options.B: Jeffrey Dean and Sanjay Ghemawat
options.C: Rob Pike and Ken Thompson
options.D: Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn

questions.question_text: The 1994 book 'Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software' by the Gang of Four catalogued how many software design patterns?

options.A: 23 design patterns
options.B: 36 design patterns
options.C: 12 design patterns
options.D: 15 design patterns

questions.question_text: The CAP theorem states that a distributed data store can guarantee at most two of which three properties simultaneously?

options.A: Confidentiality, authentication, and persistence
options.B: Consistency, availability, and partition tolerance
options.C: Correctness, accessibility, and parallelism
options.D: Concurrency, atomicity, and performance

questions.question_text: In the Paxos consensus algorithm, what is the minimum number of nodes required to tolerate f failures while still reaching agreement?

options.A: f squared nodes
options.B: f + 1 nodes
options.C: 3f + 1 nodes
options.D: 2f + 1 nodes

questions.question_text: In the MESI cache coherence protocol, what do the four letters M, E, S, and I stand for?

options.A: Mapped, Exclusive, Stale, and Invalidated
options.B: Modified, Enabled, Synchronized, and Inactive
options.C: Modified, Evicted, Shared, and Idle
options.D: Modified, Exclusive, Shared, and Invalid

questions.question_text: Tomasulo's algorithm, first implemented in the IBM System/360 Model 91, introduced which key technique to enable full out-of-order execution by eliminating false data dependencies?

options.A: Loop unrolling
options.B: Branch prediction
options.C: Register renaming
options.D: Instruction prefetching

questions.question_text: Write-ahead logging (WAL) is a technique that provides which two specific ACID properties in database systems?

options.A: Atomicity and consistency
options.B: Consistency and isolation
options.C: Isolation and durability
options.D: Atomicity and durability

questions.question_text: Software transactional memory (STM) was first proposed as a purely software-based mechanism in 1995 by which two researchers?

options.A: Maurice Herlihy and J. Eliot B. Moss
options.B: Butler Lampson and Howard Sturgis
options.C: Leslie Lamport and Barbara Liskov
options.D: Nir Shavit and Dan Touitou

questions.question_text: The LLVM compiler infrastructure project was started in 2000 at which university, under the direction of Vikram Adve and Chris Lattner?

options.A: Massachusetts Institute of Technology
options.B: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
options.C: Carnegie Mellon University
options.D: Stanford University

questions.question_text: The Spectre hardware vulnerability, disclosed in January 2018, exploits which CPU performance optimization technique to leak sensitive data through cache side channels?

options.A: Hyper-threading
options.B: Dynamic voltage and frequency scaling
options.C: Speculative execution
options.D: Out-of-order memory prefetching

questions.question_text: According to the result by Lamport, Shostak, and Pease (1982), what is the minimum number of total nodes required to tolerate f Byzantine (arbitrarily faulty) nodes?
Conflict-free replicated data types (CRDTs), formally defined by Marc Shapiro et al. in 2011, guarantee which specific form of consistency across replicas without requiring coordination?

options.A: Linearizability
options.B: Strong eventual consistency
options.C: Strict serializability
options.D: Sequential consistency

questions.question_text: Which programming language was the first to attempt a comprehensive threading memory model, influencing later efforts in C++11 and C11?

options.A: C#
options.B: Haskell
options.C: Erlang
options.D: Java

questions.question_text: In relational database query optimization, a cost-based optimizer selects an execution plan primarily by estimating what metric for each candidate plan?

options.A: The number of database tables referenced in the schema
options.B: The runtime cost in terms of I/O operations, CPU path length, and resource usage
options.C: The total number of SQL keywords parsed in the query
options.D: The size of the source code implementing each plan
